citations.narrative:
The facility is not following the program of veterinary care for vaccinations. The Program of Veterinary Care currently
prescribes dogs will be vaccinated for DAPP/Leptospirosis (7-way) at 11 weeks of age, 16 weeks of age, and annually
going forward.
A 15-week-old Boston Terrier puppy (#25-079) born on 20 August 2025 has not received a DAPP/Lepto (7-way) vaccine
as prescribed in the Program of Veterinary Care.
Failure to follow the preventative care schedule for vaccinations in the Program of Veterinary Care does not ensure the
dogs are receiving appropriate protection against contagious and deadly diseases such as distemper, parvo,
leptospirosis, and rabies which can lead to illness and discomfort to the dogs. The facility must follow the vaccination
schedule approved by the attending veterinarian in the Program of Veterinary Care to protect the dogs from deadly or
contagious diseases.
The facility has not performed the annual fecal sampling for internal parasites. The last recorded fecal sample results
were obtained on 15 January 2024. The Program of Veterinary Care states fecal exams will be performed annually on
10% of the adult dogs for intestinal parasites.
Failure to follow the parasite control program approved by the attending veterinarian may not properly protect the dogs
from parasites and may allow illness to go undetected and untreated, which may cause pain and unnecessary discomfort
to the dogs. The facility must follow the parasite control testing schedule approved by the attending veterinarian to protect
the dogs from parasites and other pests (worms, coccidia, giardia and heartworm) and have the dogs tested annually.
Correct by 19 December 2025

The facility is not following an appropriate program of veterinary care to ensure clean and healthy teeth. An adult Cavalier
King Charles Spaniel “Kate” (microchip # 991003001653400) was observed with a significant buildup of hard, brown
organic debris on the teeth of the upper jaw. The gum tissue in this area has a slightly dark red appearance indicating
inflammation. The teeth do not appear to be mobile and gum recession was not apparent. The dog appears to be normal
in weight and did not exhibit pain on oral examination. The Program of Veterinary Care prescribes teeth shall be
examined on a regular basis at a minimum of once a year.
Buildup of hard, brown debris on the teeth can be a sign of dental disease. Dental disease can be a source of pain and
infection for dogs, possibly leading to difficulty eating, weight loss, or tooth loss.
The licensee must ensure that preventative care and treatments are being regularly performed to ensure clean and
healthy teeth, in accordance with the established Program of Vet Care.
Correct by 19 December 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility is not following the program of veterinary care for vaccinations. The Program of Veterinary Care currently 
prescribes dogs will be vaccinated for DAPP/Leptospirosis (7-way) at 11 weeks of age, 16 weeks of age, and annually 
going forward. 
 A 15-week-old Boston Terrier puppy (#25-079) born on 20 August 2025 has not received a DAPP/Lepto (7-way) vaccine 
as prescribed in the Program of Veterinary Care.  
Failure to follow the preventative care schedule for vaccinations in the Program of Veterinary Care does not ensure the 
dogs are receiving appropriate protection against contagious and deadly diseases such as distemper, parvo, 
leptospirosis, and rabies which can lead to illness and discomfort to the dogs. The facility must follow the vaccination 
schedule approved by the attending veterinarian in the Program of Veterinary Care to protect the dogs from deadly or 
contagious diseases.  
 
The facility has not performed the annual fecal sampling for internal parasites. The last recorded fecal sample results 
were obtained on 15 January 2024. The Program of Veterinary Care states fecal exams will be performed annually on 
10% of the adult dogs for intestinal parasites.  
Failure to follow the parasite control program approved by the attending veterinarian may not properly protect the dogs 
from parasites and may allow illness to go undetected and untreated, which may cause pain and unnecessary discomfort 
to the dogs. The facility must follow the parasite control testing schedule approved by the attending veterinarian to protect 
the dogs from parasites and other pests (worms, coccidia, giardia and heartworm) and have the dogs tested annually.  
Correct by 19 December 2025 
3.13(a)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility is not following an appropriate program of veterinary care to ensure clean and healthy teeth. An adult Cavalier 
King Charles Spaniel “Kate” (microchip # 991003001653400) was observed with a significant buildup of hard, brown 
organic debris on the teeth of the upper jaw. The gum tissue in this area has a slightly dark red appearance indicating 
inflammation. The teeth do not appear to be mobile and gum recession was not apparent. The dog appears to be normal 
in weight and did not exhibit pain on oral examination. The Program of Veterinary Care prescribes teeth shall be 
examined on a regular basis at a minimum of once a year.  
Buildup of hard, brown debris on the teeth can be a sign of dental disease. Dental disease can be a source of pain and

infection for dogs, possibly leading to difficulty eating, weight loss, or tooth loss.  
The licensee must ensure that preventative care and treatments are being regularly performed to ensure clean and 
healthy teeth, in accordance with the established Program of Vet Care. 
Correct by 19 December 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
